diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues, potentially affecting the joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. It may cause various symptoms including leukocytosis and can affect pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
diagnoses.description: An infection of the female reproductive organs. It can lead to severe complications including infertility. It can cause lower abdominal pain, which might be related to conditions like constipation or vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Prolonged inflammation can lead to various symptoms, including constipation.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In some people, it can also affect the skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels. It may lead to systemic symptoms such as leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and interferes with the body's ability to fight infection. It can lead to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and a wide range of complications, including lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact. The disease starts as a painless sore — typically on the genitals, rectum, or mouth. Syphilis can cause various systemic symptoms if left untreated.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body. It can cause lymphadenitis among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs, but can also affect lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenitis. It may present with leukocytosis in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the formation of granulomas, it can cause lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue similar to the lining inside the uterus (the endometrium) grows outside the uterus. While not directly causing leukocytosis or lymphadenitis, it can be associated with chronic pelvic pain, which might relate to symptoms like vulvodynia.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by widespread inflammation and tissue damage, which can present with rashes, lymphadenopathy, and can potentially impact cardiovascular and musculoskeletal systems, causing symptoms like dysmenorrhea and hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues, characterized by skin hyperextensibility, joint hypermobility, and tissue fragility. It can also be associated with conditions like POTS.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacteria, transmitted by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including rashes, lymphadenopathy, and, in later stages, potentially contribute to the development of POTS.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features of several connective tissue diseases, including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and can cause symptoms such as rashes, joint hypermobility, and dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome can cause a wide array of symptoms in its different stages, including rashes and lymphadenopathy. Autoimmune manifestations can occasionally mimic symptoms such as POTS.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include rashes and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it's characterized by symptoms such as fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue. It can occasionally lead to secondary autonomic disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects joints but can have systemic impacts including rashes, lymphadenopathy, and, in some cases, secondary autonomic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) Secondary to Another Condition
diagnoses.description: While POTS itself is a diagnosis, it's often secondary to or associated with other underlying conditions, such as those listed above, which could explain the combination of symptoms including dysmenorrhea and hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body. While it does not directly cause rashes or lymphadenopathy, it can be associated with conditions like POTS and features similar to hypermobility syndromes.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Can cause delayed puberty, difficulty focusing, and, less commonly, irritability. While it's not directly linked to thrombocytosis or vaginitis, the widespread effects of hypothyroidism might indirectly affect overall health.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels. This could lead to delayed puberty and vaginitis due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Conditions
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease or juvenile idiopathic arthritis can cause systemic inflammation, leading to delayed puberty, thrombocytosis, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: This condition occurs when the body lacks sufficient iron to produce adequate amounts of hemoglobin, a substance in red blood cells that enables them to carry oxygen. Its symptoms can sometimes overlap with the symptoms listed, including difficulty focusing and irritability. It can indirectly relate to thrombocytosis through its effects on the body's red blood cell production.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism occurring in children and adolescents, leading to delayed puberty, difficulty focusing, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of this essential nutrient can result in a variety of symptoms including difficulty focusing and, to a lesser extent, irritability. While not directly linked to delayed puberty, thrombocytosis, or vaginitis, severe deficiency can affect overall growth and development in children.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys do not work effectively. It can lead to a range of symptoms, including delayed puberty and thrombocytosis due to the body's inability to filter and balance minerals and hormones.

diagnoses.name: Infections
diagnoses.description: Certain infections, particularly those affecting the reproductive system, can lead to symptoms like vaginitis. Chronic infections might also indirectly contribute to delayed puberty and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Psychological Stress or Depression
diagnoses.description: Psychological factors can manifest physically, contributing to irritability, difficulty focusing, and even impact hormonal balance, potentially affecting puberty onset indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder affecting females, where one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing. It can lead to delayed puberty and, less commonly, vaginitis due to hormone imbalances, but doesn't typically cause thrombocytosis.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome (Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia)
diagnoses.reasoning: This diagnosis accounts for the occurrence of arteriovenous malformations and angiomata. It may indirectly affect kidney function but doesn't directly explain chronic kidney disease, endometriosis, or increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly mentioned as a symptom. Chronic kidney disease could potentially lead to an increased susceptibility to infections due to immune system compromise.

diagnoses.name: Von Hippel-Lindau Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by the formation of tumors and fluid-filled sacs (cysts) in many different parts of the body. Could potentially be linked with arteriovenous malformations, increased susceptibility to infections due to overall health compromise, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Blue Rubber Bleb Nevus Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare vascular disorder is characterized by multiple venous malformations which align with angiomata and arteriovenous malformations but does not clearly explain the kidney disease, endometriosis, or increased infections.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: These disorders could explain the increased susceptibility to infections. Some types of immunodeficiency disorders could potentially be linked to kidney problems due to recurrent infections.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can cause chronic inflammation and damage in the tissues of the body. It is associated with an increased susceptibility to infections and can involve renal (kidney) damage but does not directly explain arteriovenous malformations or angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly mentioned as a symptom. While it mainly affects the uterus, endometriosis can also have systemic effects, such as increasing the risk for certain chronic diseases, but it does not explain arteriovenous malformations or angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This genetic disorder is characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys, which can lead to chronic kidney disease. It doesn't account for endometriosis, increased infection rates, arteriovenous malformations, or angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition can lead to arterial stenosis, aneurysms, or arteriovenous malformations, particularly affecting renal arteries and potentially leading to kidney disease. It doesn't directly explain endometriosis or increased infection susceptibility.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: While not a direct match for most symptoms, Turner Syndrome can involve kidney abnormalities and has been associated with hypertension, which can contribute to kidney disease. It doesn't directly explain arteriovenous malformations, angiomata, or increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses: Anemia of chronic disease (which may indirectly relate to hyperferritinemia)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
C1 Esterase Inhibitor Deficiency (Hereditary or Acquired)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) - primarily for wheezing
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's Disease)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain followed or accompanied by sensory disturbances such as flashes of light, blind spots, tingling in the arms and legs, nausea, vomiting, and increased sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including headache, nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound but does not include the sensory disturbances common in migraine with aura.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: Intensely painful headaches occurring in clusters or cyclical patterns. It's often accompanied by watery eyes, nasal congestion, or swelling around the eye on the affected side.

diagnoses.name: Tension-type Headache (TTH)
diagnoses.description: Characterized by a dull, aching head pain and scalp tenderness or neck pain. The sensation is often described as a tight band around the head. It's the most common type of headache.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high pressure in the spaces around the brain and spinal cord without an obvious reason. Symptoms can include headache, visual disturbances, and pulse-synchronous tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis
diagnoses.description: A blood clot that occurs in the venous sinuses of the brain. It can cause headache, blurred vision, fainting, and other symptoms depending on the area affected.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a sudden decrease in vision along with pain upon moving the eye. Headache and photophobia can also be present.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord. Headaches, along with visual disturbances, parasthesia, and muscle weakness, can be symptoms of the condition.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain. Symptoms can include a sudden severe headache, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and altered mental status.

diagnoses.name: Central Nervous System (CNS) Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessel walls in the brain or spine. Symptoms can include headache, confusion, seizures, and sensitivity to light, among others.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is accompanied by visual disturbances (scintillating scotoma), sensory symptoms (numbness), and can include phonophobia (sensitivity to sound) and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A common migraine type marked by recurrent headaches but lacking the specific visual or sensory warning signs (aura) seen in migraines with aura. Symptoms can include headache, phonophobia, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: Intensely painful headaches occurring in clusters over a period, occasionally accompanied by autonomic symptoms or restlessness. Phonophobia or other sensory sensitivities can be part of the symptom complex.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: The most common type of primary headache, characterized by a dull, aching head pain and tightness or pressure across the forehead or on the sides and back of the head. Numbness is not typical, might represent tension.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Neoplasms in the brain can manifest with headaches, vomiting (especially in the morning), and in later stages, can also cause numbness or weakness in parts of the body, seizures, or visual phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA may cause sudden and transient symptoms like numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body, along with headache, difficulty speaking, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, characterized by headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and at times altered consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding into the space between the brain and the tissue covering it, often causing a sudden severe headache, vomiting, phonophobia, and possible altered mental status or numbness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system marked by damage to the myelin sheath. Symptoms can include numbness or weakness in limbs, partial or complete loss of vision, and more rarely, headaches.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high pressure in the spaces around the brain, with symptoms including headache, visual disturbances like scintillation, and possibly vomiting or phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, aphasia, and possibly vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms like weakness, vomiting, and difficulty in speech (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and temporary language disturbance.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection, presenting symptoms such as vomiting, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain tissue, symptoms include weakness, vomiting, speech problems, fever, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, resulting in symptoms including weakness, difficulties in speech, and sometimes nausea.

diagnoses.name: Ischemic attack, transient (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke, such as weakness, aphasia, without lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by severe hypertension leading to brain swelling and dysfunction, manifesting in symptoms like severe headache, vomiting, weakness, and disturbances in speech.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A term for brain dysfunction that occurs when the body's internal environment is altered, causing symptoms like weakness, vomiting, and problems with speech.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Symptoms can include temporary confusion, a staring spell, or uncontrollable jerking movements of the arms and legs, often followed by weakness or temporary aphasia after the seizure (postictal state).

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation affecting multiple organ systems, skin rashes, kidney involvement (proteinuria), hematologic abnormalities including hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rashes, including psoriasiform rash; can also affect the lungs, heart, and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.details: A disease with overlapping features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including telangiectasias, proteinuria, and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Schistosomiasis
diagnoses.details: A parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma species leading to hematologic abnormalities including hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and can cause proteinuria due to kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.details: A group of autoimmune diseases causing hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues, and can involve internal organs leading to proteinuria, and vascular abnormalities including telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)
diagnoses.details: An IgA-mediated vasculitis causing purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and can lead to kidney involvement with proteinuria, and hematologic issues like thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder characterized by low platelet counts leading to easy bruising and bleeding, with some cases associated with other immune disorders that might present a psoriasiform rash.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.details: A rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), blood clots, and impaired bone marrow function leading to thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Ataxia-telangiectasia
diagnoses.details: A rare, genetic disorder that affects the nervous system, immune system, and other body systems, characterized by telangiectasias, ataxia, and immune deficiencies with various hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.details: A renal condition marked by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to proteinuria, and it can also have systemic manifestations including skin rashes and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses: Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Epstein-Barr virus)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with ITP)
Sickle Cell Disease (with vaso-occlusive crisis leading to arthropathy)
Antiphospholipid Syndrome (with thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia)
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL, with autoimmune cytopenias)
Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders (drug-induced psychosis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., Microscopic Polyangiitis, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with thrombocytopenia)
